user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_set_panic_func:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN void
MHD_set_panic_func (MHD_PanicCallback cb,
                    void *cls)
{
  if ((MHD_PanicCallback) NULL != cb)
    mhd_panic = cb;
  else
    mhd_panic = &mhd_panic_std;

  mhd_panic_cls = cls;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function MHD_set_panic_func:
typedef void
(*MHD_PanicCallback) (void *cls,
                      const char *file,
                      unsigned int line,
                      const char *reason)
...
MHD_PanicCallback mhd_panic = (MHD_PanicCallback) NULL
...
_MHD_NORETURN static void
mhd_panic_std (void *cls,
               const char *file,
               unsigned int line,
               const char *reason)
{
  (void) cls; /* Mute compiler warning. */
#ifdef HAVE_MESSAGES
  fprintf (stderr,
           _ ("Fatal error in GNU libmicrohttpd %s:%u: %s\n"),
           file,
           line,
           reason);
#else  /* ! HAVE_MESSAGES */
  (void) file;   /* Mute compiler warning. */
  (void) line;   /* Mute compiler warning. */
  (void) reason; /* Mute compiler warning. */
#endif
  abort ();
}
...
void *mhd_panic_cls = NULL
...
MHD_PanicCallback mhd_panic = (MHD_PanicCallback) NULL
...
void *mhd_panic_cls = NULL
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The rule targets pointers that could be declared to point to const-qualified data. I have not flagged fragments that already use const-qualified pointer types (for example the const char * parameters "file" and "reason"), nor non-pointer/irrelevant code such as the calls to fprintf, abort, or the (void) casts that merely suppress warnings. Functionality-related statements (fprintf/abort) and uses of const-qualified parameters do not need investigation for Rule 8.13. The fragments listed above are the code locations where non-const pointer types (notably the opaque "cls" pointer and its storage/typedef) appear and therefore warrant review for possible const-qualification. No other pointer declarations or uses in the provided excerpts require further scrutiny under this rule.
